FacilityName: Chevron Phillips Chemical Company LP - Cedar Bayou

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chevron Phillips Cedar Bayou facility is a manufacturing facility of Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, headquartered in The Woodlands, Texas.  The Cedar Bayou Plant is located on the north side of Interstate 10 between Cedar Bayou and Sjolander Road, and is situated on approximately 1,000 acres.  The plant was initially built by Gulf Oil and began operating in 1963.  In 1984, it became part of Chevron through the Chevron-Gulf merger, and is currently part of the Chevron Phillips Chemical Company, LP, as the result of a joint venture.

The plant produces simple olefins, including ethylene and propylene, and derivatives including polyethylene resins, normal alpha olefins, and polyalphaolefins.  These products are primarily intermediates which our customers use to produce finished consumer products such as plastics and packaging, biodegradable detergents, synthetic lubricants and hydraulic fluids, and waxes.  Chemicals used at the facility that exceed the RMP threshold quantity include flammable mixtures which may contain Methane, Ethylene, Butene, Hexene, Ethane, Methanol, Propane and Propylene; and toxics such as boron trifluoride, aqueous ammonia, chlorine and titanium tetrachloride.  


ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

Process Safety Management at the Cedar Bayou plant complies with the requirements of both the OSHA PSM standard and EPA RMP regulation.  As detailed in site procedure EHSPP 11.12 RMP Overview, the Cedar Bayou plant manages all aspects of process safety through employee participation at all levels in the organization.  Each element of the PSM and RMP standards is assigned to a responsible organizational position to maintain the systems that ensure compliance with regulatory requirements and management of that aspect of process safety.  Some of the details of this management system include:

1) Employee Participation is outlined in site procedure EHSPP 1.20 Employee Participation Policy and includes the plant VPP STAR teams who help to drive safety by

focusing individual work groups on safety activities and issues in their area.
2)  Process Safety Information management is outlined in site procedure EHSPP 1.30 Cedar Bayou Process Safety Management File System which assigns a responsible position to each type of information item of process safety compliance documentation.
3)  Site procedure EHSPP 11.20 Process Hazard Analysis provides site-specific details on the conduct and disposition of all unit PHAs and references to corporate PHA procedures, all of which provide oversight and management of the performance of PHAs and include relevant timelines for report development and review, recommendation development and tracking and final report issuance.  The corporate procedures for conduct of PHAs and the qualitative assessment of risk include consideration of off-site consequences and harm to the environment or the public.
4)   All operating procedures are developed, reviewed and kept current by personnel experienced in the operation of that portion of the unit or in that job or task. Operations procedures are developed and managed according to the site policy "Compliance Standards for Standard Operating Procedures", Health, safety and environmental procedures forllow EHS P&P 1.25 Policy and Procedure Management Process, and maintenance procedures follow M0206 -- Maintenance Procedure Development and Review Process. 
5)  Training for process operators is managed by the plant Training Department and includes rigorous initial hire or job transfer training with classroom and on-the-job elements and ongoing refresher training for experienced personnel on a frequency determined by individual need or on a maximum three-year cycle.
6)  The site Mechanical Integrity Program encompasses several functional groups of the Maintenance Department and includes written procedures for all maintenance activities as well as inspection and testing schedules, procedures and reports as required by both PSM and RMP.
7)  Changes to equipme

nt or operations in a covered process follow site procedure EHSPP 4.02 Management of Change Process.  A company-wide software system aids in managing such changes and provides a means of controlling the change process through required safety and health evaluation, appropriate approval, and pre-startup safety review steps.
8)  Site procedure EHSPP 4.75 Pre-startup Safety Review (PSSR) details the conduct of a pre-startup safety review for changes requiring this type of follow-up to ensure system integrity before introduction of hazardous chemicals.
9)  Audits for compliance with both the PSM and RMP regulatory requirements are conducted at least every three years according to the corporate auditing protocol.  Some audits or evaluations of individual process safety elements may be conducted in the intervening years according to a specific need for that area.
10)  Incidents that occur in a covered process are investigated through application of site procedure EHSPP 3.12 Incident Investigation which provides guidance on use of the appropriate investigation method as well as development of investigation reports and corrective actions or recommendations to prevent recurrence.  A company-wide software system aids in tracking both the investigations and the resulting recommendations and their resolution.
11)  The site safe work practices are managed through several procedures including EHSPP 4.05 Entrance Into a Process Area, EHSPP 4.18 Safe Work/Hot Work Permit Procedure, EHSPP 4.22 Initial Equipment Opening, EHSPP 3.80 Hazardous Energy Control Lock/Tag/Try, and EHSPP 3.90 Confined Space Entry.
12)  Management of contract employees follows site procedure EHSPP 7.10 Contractor Safety Program which includes selection of contractors based on their safety performance, training of contract workers on the hazards where they will be working in the plant, and periodic evaluation of the performance of both the individual contract employees and the contract company in general at the

Cedar Bayou plant.
13)  The Cedar Bayou plant has developed an Integrated Contingency Plan to guide responses to various types of emergencies and events.  This ICP includes procedures on responding to hazardous material releases, both large and small, and coordination with on- and off-site responders. 
 
The Cedar Bayou plant became an OSHA STAR worksite in the Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) in 1997. The site was recertified to STAR status by OSHA in 2000, 2004, and 2008.  This voluntary program is a partnership between OSHA and industry to recognize and encourage excellence and continuous improvement in safety programs.  STAR certification represents the highest form of recognition OSHA can give a company for outstanding safety performance.

Chemical specific preventions for flammable chemical mixture OCAs containing 1,3 butadiene might include: pressure relief valves, hydrocarbon area detectors, remote valves to isolate the process, and administrative controls on tank levels.  
Chemical specific preventions for Boron Trifluoride toxic OCAs include: connecting only one tube of a tube trailer at a time, providing video camera surveillance of the tube trailer area, remote-operated valves to isolate the trailer and reduce the amount released, manual BF3 alarms in the unit to notify personnel in the immediate area of a release, and a water deluge system with remote activation to minimize the release footprint (BF3 is drawn to water).  A large capacity truck is used to minimize tubing connections and to decrease truck traffic on roadways.
Chemical specific preventions for titanium tetrachloride toxic OCAs include: an operator in attendance during the entire titanium tetrachloride unloading process can isolate the system remotely while the catalyst supervisor audits the unloading process.  Unloading hoses are designed for a higher pressure service than the system would normally require.  These stainless steel braided hoses are provided with additional support to pre

vent unnecessary binding or crimping.  When not in use, the hoses remain hooked up under nitrogen pressure to prevent moisture from degrading the hose integrity.
Chemical specific preventions for chlorine toxic OCAs include: replacing the transfer hose every year (the hose is Kynar coated stainless steel braiding with a Teflon lining).  There are four chlorine sensors located at all four quadrants of the chlorine cylinder pad which initiate a chlorine alarm in the Waste Treatment and main utilities/1592 control rooms.  In addition, lights flash and horns sound in the area of the chlorine cylinders.  An automatic shut-off valve is mounted on the chlorine cylinder after installing the hose during change-out of the cylinder.  The valve will close automatically if there is a chlorine leak detected.  The valve can also be manually closed from the Waste Treatment control room for the cooling tower chlorine cylinder and from the main utilities control room for the clarifier cylinder.  The valve is tested each time a cylinder is changed.  After changing the cylinder, all connections are checked for leaks. Cylinders are connected at the vapor valve and not the liquid valve.  Vapor releases would be smaller than liquid releases.  Cylinders have been located outside of areas with fire threat potential, and are protected against vehicle impact with concrete and metal posts.
Chemical specific preventions for aqueous ammonia toxic OCAs include:  the containment basin is designed for full volume release; the tank vent space is vented back to the delivery truck during unloading process to minimize air emissions; and an operator is in attendance during unloading operation and can block in the truck if needed.  The ammonia tank is filled by an overhead line with a dip tube into the vessel.  A manual alarm/plant emergency alarm pull station on the unit is used to notify personnel in the immediate area of a release. 


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Alarm Systems
Cedar Bayou has an intern

al plant wide alarm system for fires and emergencies.  In addition, the Baytown alarm system can be activated in the event of incidents with potential offsite consequences.

Emergency Responders
To protect onsite workers and property, Cedar Bayou has fully trained volunteer responders covering all four rotating shifts to ensure 24-hour coverage.  Each shift has a Fire & Safety Specialist (Incident Commander), Fire Brigade members, and Emergency Medical Service/Rescue members.  ERT members receive training in all recognized categories of response (Fire, Haz-Mat, Emergency Medical Treatment, Rescue and Environmental Protection).  The ERT has won several championships at International Rescue & Emergency Care Association competitions.   

Communications Link to Offsite Responders
The Cedar Bayou Emergency Operations Center (EOC) is the central communication point for internal and external responders.  The EOC is staffed by Management, Environmental, and Health & Safety personnel, as well as individuals who are on call, per the facility Incident Command System.  The City of Baytown emergency assistance is obtained by calling 911 and industry assistance is available through the mutual aid groups listed below.  The plant Safety Supervisor participates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  In 1998, the Cedar Bayou plant initially shared release scenario information with the LEPC.  

Mobile Fire Protection Equipment
A?  Combination Mobile Emergency Command Post/One-Ton Fire Truck with 250 gallons of foam solution.  
A?  E-One 2,000 gpm Foam Aerial with 75 ft aerial ladder
A?  2,000 gpm Foam Pumper carrying 500 gallons of foam and 500 gallons of water.
A?  A?-Ton Ford Fire Truck with equipment trailer 
A?  Two 2000X6000 gpm trailer mounted A?Big GunA? monitors.
A?  A fully-equipped ambulance placed in service in 2005.
A?  A plant fire water system with ground-level and elevated fire monitors.  
A?  Additional 1 A?, 2 A?, and large diameter hose carried on low b

oy trailers.

Members of Mutual Aid Group with Other Plants
Cedar Bayou is a member of both the Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA) and Mutual Aid of Mont Belvieu (MAMB).  CIMA and MAMB offer additional emergency response assistance if on-site responders and equipment cannot handle an emergency.  The EOC has the authority to request assistance from outside mutual aid groups.  Cedar Bayou also offers assistance through the mutual aid groups to offsite emergencies.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Accidents with On-Site Effects
There has been one accident with on-site effects in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances and meeting the RMP criteria for accidents:
11/01/2006 PAO-1795; a flash fire occurred when hydrogen was released to the atmosphere during an attempt to clear debris from piping.  An employee was burned by the flash fire and received minor first aid.  Minimal equipment damage occurred.

Accidents with Off-Site Effects
There were no accidents with off-site effects in the last five years involving chemicals that are on the 40 CFR PART 68.130 List of Substances.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

As part of the Cedar Bayou plant commitment to continuously improving the safety of our processes, some of the initiatives and measures that have been taken or are on-going include:

1. Completed a risk-based Building Siting study based on OSHA and API RP guidelines to determine the risk to building occupants from external explosion, fire, or toxic release and developed a plan.  

2. Adding Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) to the processes which meet ANSI/ISA-84.01-1996 and IEC 61511 standards requirements as determined by hazard and operability (HAZOP) and Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) reviews.

3. To monitor the overall effectiveness of the facilityA?s PSM programs, Process Safety Metrics are generated routinely and reviewed with all units, departments, and Cedar Bayou Leadership Team.

4.  Plant equipm
ent is being assessed for possible Corrosion Under Insulation (CUI) and corrective and preventative measures are being taken to address this potential hazard when necessary.
